title: Whispers of Love in Vatican City

places.generalDescription: Trevi Fountain is a stunning rococo fountain in Rome, designed by Nicola Salvi and completed in 1762. The fountain features sculpted figures and is fed by an aqueduct. Its dramatic design includes an imperious sculpture of Oceanus commanding rushing waters. The location of the fountain adds to its unique drama, as it is squeezed into the confluence of three streets, which may have inspired its name 'Trevi' from 'tre vie.'

sources.snippet: Filled with fountains, ancient ruins, and charming squares, the historic center of Rome is already pretty romantic to see during the day. However, exploring it at night makes for an even more special experience. While crowds of tourists typically swarm this area during the day, the atmosphere is a lot quieter at night, making it the perfect time to go for a romantic stroll or to try some fun activities together!
sources.shortName: 10 Super Romantic Things to Do in Rome

sources.snippet: It is nighttime and the lights illuminate the wonderful Trevi Fountain: that's the perfect time to throw your coin in the fountain and make a wish. Then, look to the right: on the external side of the fountain is a rectangular basin with two small spouts, the fountain of lovers. According to ancient legends of the Roman tradition, if you drink at this fountain, you will stay in love and remain forever faithful.
sources.shortName: Sette cose romantiche da fare a Roma

sources.snippet: The Trevi Fountain is one of Rome‚Äôs most iconic monuments, known for its beauty and romantic atmosphere. The Fountain has been the protagonist of many famous movies, including La Dolce Vita by Federico Fellini, with the famous scene of Anita Ekberg walking inside the fountain. The best-known tradition is the throwing of three coins into the fountain as a hope of returning to Rome.
sources.shortName: Romantic weekend in Rome: the most romantic places you cannot miss

sources.snippet: Tossing coins in the Trevi Fountain ‚Äì probably the pinnacle of Roman romance ‚Äì toss coins together into the waters of the baroque wishing fountain and maybe your wish will come true!. This is the most magnificent and famous fountain in the city, and one of the most beautiful in the world. (See also the article ‚ÄúThe perfect checklist for a trip to Rome‚Äù).
sources.shortName: Activities for couples in Rome

sources.snippet: A must-see for anyone on a Roman holiday, the Trevi Fountain has captivated travellers for 400 years. It‚Äôs featured in some of Hollywood‚Äôs great love stories too, parts of both Roman Holiday and Fellini‚Äôs Dolce Vita were filmed at the fountain. Through time, it has acquired a reputation for being the place for young lovers to visit.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things To Do in Rome | Sightseeing

sources.snippet: The Trevi Fountain is the classic proposal spot in Rome, and for good reason. The Baroque masterpiece, with its cascading waters and stunning architecture, radiates romance. Plus, legend says tossing a coin into the fountain ensures your return to Rome‚Äîwhy not toss three coins and seal the deal?
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Places to Propose in Rome, Italy

sources.snippet: As one of Rome's most iconic landmarks, visiting the Trevi Fountain on your romantic trip away has to be at the top of the list. With romance, sometimes the more cliche an activity is, the better. Get your coins at the ready and toss them in together as you make a wish with your partner.
sources.shortName: What Are The Most Romantic Things To Do In Rome?

sources.snippet: It is not only the most beautiful fountain in the city, but also one of the most romantic places in Rome and a must on every guided tour of Rome. Tradition has it that if you throw three coins into the water of the Trevi Fountain you will marry the love of your life.

sources.snippet: Don‚Äôt forget to throw a coin into the famous Trevi fountain for luck. Legend has it, you will then be sure to return to Rome in the future. And if you throw in three coins, the fountain promises marriage!

sources.snippet: Heading into the centro storico there are the old favourites, the Trevi Fountain and the Spanish Steps, both of which are at their most magical when illuminated by night.

places.name: Trevi Fountain

reviews.text:
It was truly impressive to see in person. I completely understood the hype when I visited yesterday.
I arrived around 10 a.m. and initially expected it to be packed, but surprisingly, it wasn't. I guess most people went as early as 6 a.m. to avoid the crowds. There's a queue if you want to go down closer to the water, but you can still take great photos without waiting in line. People were also very considerate, stepping aside after taking their pictures so others could have their turn.

The Trevi Fountain is one of Rome's most iconic landmarks, and it truly lives up to the hype. The baroque design is stunning, with water cascading over intricate sculptures that seem almost alive. It's especially magical at night, when the fountain is beautifully lit and the atmosphere feels timeless.

Be prepared for crowds - it's almost always busy, and getting a quiet moment can be tricky. Still, tossing a coin into the fountain is a must-do tradition, and the energy of people from all over the world gathered in one place only adds to the charm.

A place that captures the romance and grandeur of Rome perfectly - unmissable.

The Trevi Fountain is absolutely stunning and a must see if you're visiting Rome. However, it's extremely crowded and the lines can get very long. If you want to enjoy it without the masses, I highly recommend going early in the morning, this way you can avoid the queues, take in the beautiful views, throw your coin, and get a great photo. At night, the fountain is beautifully lit, which makes it the best time to experience, it's magic.

places.generalDescription: The Colosseum, also known as the Flavian Amphitheater, is a monumental 3-tiered Roman amphitheater located in the center of Rome. It has stood for over 2,000 years as a symbol of Ancient Rome's architectural ingenuity and engineering advancements. This iconic structure entertained more than 50,000 spectators with gladiatorial fights, mock sea battles, and exotic animal hunts for over 400 years.

sources.snippet: This ancient amphitheater is a symbol of resilience and enduring love. If you want a quieter spot, head to Colle Oppio Park nearby‚Äîit offers panoramic views of the Colosseum without the hustle and bustle. Insider tip: Book a VIP after-hours tour or grab a Turbopass Rome city pass to enjoy exclusive access and a private proposal moment inside this historic wonder.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Places to Propose in Rome, Italy

sources.snippet: Night tour of the Colosseum ‚Äì The Colosseum is perhaps the most famous amphitheater of all. The iconic location is extremely romantic and less touristy at night, so you will experience it in a more relaxed atmosphere. We recommend that you have dinner on one of the rooftops overlooking the Colosseum or take a dip in the jacuzzi overlooking it.

places.name: Colosseum

reviews.text:
Visiting the Colosseum is like stepping back in time to ancient Rome. This iconic amphitheater, with its massive structure and historical significance, is one of the most impressive landmarks I've ever seen. Walking through the corridors and seating areas, you can almost imagine the crowds and the events that once took place here.

The guided tours and audio guides provide fascinating insights into Roman history, gladiator battles, and architectural techniques. The surrounding area, including the Roman Forum, adds even more context and makes the visit even more enriching.

Highlights:
‚Ä¢	Stunning ancient architecture and engineering marvel.
‚Ä¢	Informative guided tours and exhibits.
‚Ä¢	Amazing photo opportunities both inside and outside.

Tips:
‚Ä¢	Book tickets online in advance to skip long lines.
‚Ä¢	Visit early in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid crowds.
‚Ä¢	Wear comfortable shoes ‚Äì there's a lot of walking and uneven surfaces.

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
A must-visit for anyone traveling to Rome! The Colosseum is truly a symbol of ancient history and Roman greatness.

Was a great experience, truly amazing structure, they don't build like that anymore.
Must visit, if you are in Rome, please make sure to buy tickets in advance, and bring your ID with your ticket.

The line was not too bad, we got just a regular visit, which includes just walking around, I would recommend a full experience, this way you get to go under and see more cool spaces‚Ä¶ those tickets are also on the web, but you have to scroll all the way down the page ‚Ä¶ some what strange, we did miss it and by the time we realized it it was too late, everything was booked:(

Bring some water with you and stay hydrated, very important!
There is water available throughout the visit ‚Ä¶ but you have to look for it.

Highly recommended.

What an absolutely amazing experience, step back in to the time of gladiators, chariots and slaves, the sheer size of the place is stunning considering how long ago it was built. When you close your eyes you can almost hear the roar of the crowd as they bay for blood at the spectacle unfolding before them. There are plenty of opportunities to take photos and selfies here but be advised there is a lot of walking around involved and some of the ground is uneven so be sure to have decent shoes on. I had an awesome time visiting and would highly recommend. Buying your ticket in advance is a must as that way you get to jump the queue.

places.generalDescription: St. Peter's Basilica is a Late Renaissance church designed by a team of renowned architects, including Michelangelo and Carlo Maderno. It is considered the holiest church in Christendom and one of only four Major Basilicas in the world.

sources.snippet: The beating heart of Catholicism, St. Peter's draws millions of pilgrims every year; they arrive from every part of the world to unite in prayer and receive the Pope's blessing. The construction of the Basilica that now dominates St. Peter's Square began April 18, 1506, when the Church was headed by Pope Julius II, and was completed in 1626, during the papacy of Pope Urban VII. The Square, rather, was completed in 1667. On the same site - before the present-day Basilica - stood another basilica from the 4th Century; it had been commissioned by Roman Emperor Constantine I. A string of architects worked on the Basilica: Bramante, whose collaborators included Giuliano da Sangallo; Raphael, who also collaborated with Giuliano da Sangallo, as well as Fr√† Giocondo; Antonio da Sangallo the Younger, collaborating with Baldassarre Peruzzi; Michelangelo, Pirro Ligorio and Jacopo Barozzi da Vignola; Giacomo Della Porta, with help from Domenico Fontana; Carlo Maderno and, of course, from 1629 forward, Gian Lorenzo Bernini.
sources.shortName: St. Peter's Basilica and the Vatican Museums

sources.snippet: The Basilica was designed by a group of architects that included Michelangelo, Bernini, Maderno and Bramante. The entire building is filled with incredible art, especially from the Renaissance and Baroque eras, including Michelangelo's Pieta, Bernini's Baldacchino and of course, the mosaic-covered dome designed by Michelangelo. While there is some explanatory signage, the best way to learn about the art, architecture, and chapels is by taking a tour.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Guide to Exploring Vatican City: Tips and Highlights for Every Traveller

sources.snippet: While you‚Äôre there, keep your eyes peeled for Michelangelo‚Äôs breathtaking Piet√† sculpture. And be sure to look up at the magnificent dome‚Äîalso designed by Michelangelo himself, it‚Äôs not only an architectural triumph but also one of the largest domes in the world, a true masterpiece that dominates the Roman skyline. Beneath the majestic St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica lies the Vatican Necropolis, a site less frequented by tourists.
sources.shortName: Things to do & see in Vatican City, the country inside Rome

sources.snippet: No exploration of Vatican City would be complete without a visit to St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica. This monumental structure is not only a symbol of Catholicism but also a masterpiece of Renaissance architecture. Upon entering, visitors are greeted by Michelangelo‚Äôs poignant Piet√† in the first chapel on the right, alongside Antonio Canova‚Äôs monument to Clement XIII and Pollaiolo‚Äôs tomb of Innocent VIII on opposite sides.
sources.shortName: Vatican City: what to see besides the Vatican Museums

sources.snippet: Also part of the Vatican, St Peter‚Äôs is one of the holiest Catholic churches in the world and a beautiful example of Renaissance architecture. Climb to the top of the dome for 360-degree views of St Peter‚Äôs Square and the city of Rome, or admire the many statues and artworks, including the Piet√† ‚Äì Michelangelo‚Äôs only signed work. If you‚Äôre Catholic, you can even be married here.

sources.snippet: St. Peter's Basilica is the world's largest basilica of Christianity, and a remarkable example of Renaissance architecture. Primarily designed by by Bramante, Bernini, Michelangelo, and Maderno, this church is a must-see for those visiting Rome. Apart from being a center of religion, St. Peter's Basilica is also home to numerous works of Renaissance art.

sources.snippet: One of the largest churches in the world, St Peter‚Äôs Basilica lies on top of the Vatican Hill. Its impressive dome towers over the other city‚Äôs buildings and it has served as inspiration for many other cathedrals around the world. Construction began for the new Basilica in 1506, when the old Basilica had been torn down and wasn‚Äôt finished until 1626.

places.name: Saint Peter‚Äôs Basilica

reviews.text:
One of the best experiences I've ever had in any basilica. The place is huge and every detail is breathtaking: marble sculptures, vibrant colors, and an atmosphere that truly moves you. We visited on a Sunday and were lucky enough to hear the chants during mass, which made the visit even more special.

Despite the crowds, this is an absolute must-see. Entrance is free and there are public restrooms available. The dress code seemed more relaxed than expected  some women were given disposable covers for their shoulders, but many people wore shorts or short skirts without any issues.

Tip: arrive early. We went around 7:30 a.m. and only waited 15 minutes to get in. A few hours later, the line had already quadrupled. Don't miss the papal tombs, which are free to visit, and if you're up for the adventure, climb to the top of the dome for a truly magnificent view of Vatican City. The gift shop also has plenty of nice souvenir options.

A beautiful, famous, and unforgettable basilica. Highly recommended!

Visiting St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City is truly a once-in-a-lifetime experience. The sheer grandeur of the architecture leaves you in awe the moment you step inside. The massive dome designed by Michelangelo is breathtaking, both from below and when you climb to the top. The view from the dome is worth the effort ‚Äì Rome spreads out in every direction, and seeing St. Peter's Square from above is unforgettable.

Inside, every corner is filled with art, history, and devotion. The Piet√† by Michelangelo is simply mesmerizing, and the ornate altars, mosaics, and sculptures showcase centuries of craftsmanship and faith. The atmosphere is peaceful yet majestic, giving you a deep sense of spirituality, whether you are religious or just an admirer of culture.

Practical tips: entry to the basilica itself is free, but the dome climb has a small fee. Lines can be very long, so it's best to arrive early in the morning. Dress modestly, as it is a place of worship. Security checks are strict but efficient.

Overall, this is not just a landmark ‚Äì it's a symbol of history, art, and devotion that should not be missed. Absolutely worth visiting, and I would highly recommend it to anyone coming to Rome.

‚≠ê 5/5 ‚Äì Must-Visit: Saint Peter's Basilica

üöå Getting There
After lunch, we tried to hop on a bus, but most were full! Luckily, after walking about one station's distance, we found a small space to squeeze in-saving a 20+ minute walk.

‚ú® Stunning & Historic
The basilica is breathtaking, and this year is special because the Holy Door, which opens only every 25 years, is still accessible! A must-see before it closes again.

‚è∞ Queue & Tickets
We arrived on 6 September around 3‚ÄØpm. The queue was long, with some staff trying to convince visitors to buy an express ticket for ‚Ç¨25-but the entrance is free! We queued patiently and got in after 30 minutes, with another 30 minutes to walk through the Holy Door. Totally acceptable for a weekend visit.

üëó Dress Code & Security
Wear appropriate clothing (shoulders and knees covered). They provide cloth covers if needed and screen all bags before entry.

üìñ Tips for Meaningful Visit
Going with a tour guide adds context, but you can also read or Google the stories while waiting. It's especially rewarding if you get to witness the mass in progress-we were lucky to see one!

‚ú® Overall Impression
Saint Peter's Basilica is iconic and awe-inspiring. Plan for a bit of a wait, dress respectfully, and soak in the rich history-it's truly unforgettable.

places.generalDescription: Piazza Navona is a stunning square in Rome with a rich history dating back to the 1st century A.D. It was originally the site of Domitian Stadium, built to introduce Greek-style athletics and sports to the Roman public. However, it fell into disuse over time and was transformed into a beautiful Baroque piazza in the 17th century under Pope Innocent X.

sources.snippet: Rome‚Äôs most enchanting neighborhood is centered around the Baroque-style Piazza Navona. From well-kept Renaissance architecture to impressive fountains, this area is a sensory overload of beauty. The rates are among the highest in Rome for posh hotels, chic B&Bs, and upscale private apartments, but it‚Äôs worth the extra cost if you can.
sources.shortName: Where To Stay in Rome in 2024: Best Neighborhoods and Hotels

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre going to make your love official, why not go where everyone goes: to Piazza Navona. The beautiful oblong square, decorated with three Baroque-era fountains and flanked by cafes, museums, and a church, is the most iconic of Rome‚Äôs squares. It‚Äôs also ground zero for public displays of affection, at least among young Romans.
sources.shortName: 9 Romantic Places to Propose in Rome
Most Romantic Places In Rome

places.name: Piazza Navona

reviews.text:
The fountain showcasing the Romanian architecture is treasure to eyes. If you are at Rome do visit it.
This is a famous public square built on the site of the ancient Stadium of Domitian. It is a major landmark and a hub for restaurants and pizzerias. Many restaurants in this area cater to tourists, but some are known for their authentic Roman cuisine and pizza.

One of many piazza in Rome where people segregates at for all sorts of purposes. Be amazed by the fountains here and the obelisk which seems to be Egyptian more than Rome or Greek. From here, you can easily walk to the pantheon to spend hours at. Lots of restaurants and stores are here for local food and cuisines. Careful of the non-locals street peddlers. There are videos online of what they do.

Piazza Navona was a total hit with the kiddos! We spent hours lounging in the courtyard, sipping coffee while they ran around, mesmerized by the fountains and street performers. The restaurants were so inviting, and the art shops were a treasure trove of creativity. The whole vibe was just so relaxed and happy, and the sunshine made everything feel even more magical. We ended up staying way longer than planned - it was just one of those special spots that makes you feel like you're soaking up the essence of Rome.

places.generalDescription: The Roman Forum is a sprawling archaeological site in Rome, featuring ancient temples, squares, and government buildings dating back 2,000 years. It's more of an open-air museum than a conventional one and is a must-visit for first-time visitors to Rome. Despite the crowds and the need to use your imagination due to the ruins, it offers a glimpse into the glory of the ancient empire.

sources.snippet: The Roman Forum and Palatine Hillare part of the ancient city of Rome. Explore the ancient ruins, iconic pillars, historical buildings and winding cobbled streets with your partner while you literally walk in the footsteps of emperors. Pinching myself that I happened to be here for last night‚Äôs sunset.
sources.shortName: Our Guide to the Most Romantic Places in Rome

sources.snippet: For history lovers, the terrace behind Piazza del Campidoglio is a hidden gem. Overlooking the ancient ruins of the Roman Forum, this spot feels like stepping back in time. It‚Äôs quieter than most tourist areas, making it perfect for a private, meaningful proposal.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Places to Propose in Rome, Italy

places.name: Roman Forum

reviews.text: The Roman Forum is like walking through an open-air museum of ancient history. The ruins give a real sense of how grand the city once was, and exploring the site is both fascinating and atmospheric. It can take time to fully appreciate, but the views-especially from the Palatine Hill-make it unforgettable.

Pretty cool place to visit, it was included with our colosseum tickets. Lots to walk outside, with hills and stairs, lots of ruins and some gardens. Several restrooms and vending machines with cold drinks and snacks along the way. We walked for about 1.5 hours but still didn't see all of it.

Must go for the ones who love the ancients, and recommend in general to admire these historical ruins. The place is huge, you can walk around for 2 hours at least if you take your time to appreciate and enjoy it. You may consider coming early for fewer crowds, and avoiding the heat, we went with the standard ticket and felt satisfied.

places.generalDescription: The Pantheon, a temple built in 118-125 A.D., is one of Rome's most iconic and well-preserved ancient Roman monuments. Originally dedicated to all deities, it now serves as a Catholic church. The structure features a dome and Renaissance tombs, including that of Raphael. Visitors are often impressed by its peculiar design, myths, and stories related to the hole in its roof and special astronomical light effects.

sources.snippet: Every visitor to Rome goes inside the Pantheon (and if they don‚Äôt they should!) to admire its impressive dome, one of the true miracles of ancient Roman engineering. What most people don‚Äôt know is that there‚Äôs also an amazing vantage point where you can marvel at this triumph of Roman architecture from the exterior. Even better: it serves drinks.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Romantic overlooked things do in Rome

places.name: Pantheon

reviews.text:
No ticket to heaven, but still worth the entry fee. You walk into the Pantheon expecting a big old Roman building‚Ä¶ and then you look up. Boom!!! The dome. That perfect circle of sky staring back at you. Suddenly you're quiet, and so is everyone else.

Yes, you now need a ticket (thanks, modern tourism), and no, you can't climb anything or whisper too loudly - but trust me, it's worth it.

This place has survived nearly 2,000 years of weather, popes, emperors, tourists, and pigeons. Rain literally falls through the hole in the middle of the dome, and nobody bothers to cover it -because why mess with perfection?

It's peaceful, powerful, and impossibly well-preserved. You feel small here, in a good way.No need to understand the architecture or the history (although it's epic). Just walk in, look up, and try not to say ‚Äúwow‚Äù out loud.

One of the oldest buildings to stand the test of time.
It's best to make reservations ahead of time. Careful though to arrive on the day and time of your ticket. They enforce the time slot.
There is also the opportunity to buy a ticket at a CASH ONLY register. There is a line, but once they open it up, it moves fast.

We just did a walk by today as we didn't have much time.  We will be back for a more thorough visit next week.
Like a lot of Rome,  it continues to amaze us that these structures are still standing after so many years and are just wonderful to see!

places.address: Piazza della Rotonda, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Located not far from St. Peter's Basilica in Rome, Castel Sant'Angelo is a circular 2nd-century castle that has served various purposes throughout history. Initially built as Emperor Hadrian's mausoleum, it later became a stronghold for the city and was contested by powerful Roman families. In 1367, Pope Urban V received its keys, marking the end of the Avignon exile.

sources.snippet: Also known as the Mausoleum of Hadrian, the Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo is a fortress located on the right bank of the Tiber River. Built by Rome‚Äôs Emperor Hadrian in the 2nd century as a resting place for him and his family when they died, the cylindrical mausoleum was converted into a military fortress in the 14th century and now serves as a museum. Whilst technically located in Rome, Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo still gets a place on this Vatican list of top things to do for its not-so-secret passageway that leads right into the Vatican.
sources.shortName: Top things to do at Vatican City

sources.snippet: One of my favorite romantic spots in Rome is Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelo at night. Only at night. During the day it swarms with tourists. But when they (occasionally) open it up after dark, it‚Äôs uncrowded and the evocative mood recalls furtive affairs, forbidden trysts, and tales of heroic lovers risking the dungeon in order to fulfill their hearts‚Äô desires. . .
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Rome

sources.snippet: Castel Sant‚ÄôAngelois close to the Ponte Sant‚ÄôAngelo bridge and beautifully lit at night. It‚Äôs occasionally open in the evenings, which is a chance to explore the castle when it‚Äôs much quieter than normal. Now housing a museum, it was originally built as the Mausoleum of Hadrian and later converted to a papal fortress.

places.name: Castel Sant'Angelo

reviews.text:
From the outside it doesn't seem much to show, but interior offers much to see and explore. With unique architectural design, decoration, museum of the past, bar and amazing view from the high stories it's definitely worth of visiting. They do offer audible tours if you are interested into deeper history. Just for a quick peek I would suggest like hour-hour and half of your time. However I would consider spending more of your time to properly explore it and enjoy the scene.

Reservation is not required, but in peak season is good to plan ahead

As we are EU citizens and under 25 the tickets were (as in every big sight) very cheap (2‚Ç¨ each). We spent around 1 hour there. Quite interesting to explore the history of the building. In the upper museum part you woll see some reconstructions/models of the past. Very interesting.

Once you get up to the top, the view is amazing. One of the best for that price.

We can really recommend going there and spending around 1-1.5 hours.

May 2025. Cool castle. Minimal line when we got there in the mid-afternoon. Reminded me of Helm's Deep in Lord of the Rings at times. Awesome views throughout as well. It's Rome after all, so it also had a good amount of art and frescoes.

places.generalDescription: The Sistine Chapel, located within the Vatican Museums, is a renowned masterpiece of Renaissance art. Its unassuming exterior belies the breathtaking treasures within, including Michelangelo's iconic ceiling fresco and the Last Judgement on the altar wall. reviews.text: Piazza del Campidoglio is one of the most beautiful squares in Rome, designed by Michelangelo, offering a stunning view of the city and its historical atmosphere. The square is located at the top of Capitoline Hill and is surrounded by significant buildings, including the Capitoline Museums. The statue of Marcus Aurelius at the center of the square is one of its main attractions. This space is perfect for walks, photography, and admiring Roman architecture. If you're in Rome, a visit to Piazza del Campidoglio is a must for all history and culture enthusiasts.

The Capitoline Hill square, delightfully designed by Michelangelo. On one side, the remnants of pagan Rome (Roman Forum), and on the other, Christian-era Rome (Vatican, Roma City Center)‚Ä¶ An important location to enjoy a panoramic view of both landscapes. If you enter through the passage on the right, across from the Cordonata, you can witness the unique view of the Roman Forum. This spot is among my favorite places in Rome. Especially at sunset, the old city comes to life with its crimson hues. Be sure to experience it and enjoy the view accompanied by live music!

Piazza del Campidoglio (often anglicized as Capitoline Hill Square) is one of the most elegant and historically significant squares in Rome.

Location & Significance
‚Ä¢	Located on Capitoline Hill (Campidoglio in Italian), one of the Seven Hills of Rome, and historically the political and religious heart of the ancient city.
‚Ä¢	Overlooks the Roman Forum and is near Piazza Venezia, making it a central point for visitors exploring ancient Rome.

Designed by Michelangelo
‚Ä¢	In 1536, Michelangelo Buonarroti was commissioned by Pope Paul III to redesign the square.
‚Ä¢	The trapezoidal shape, geometric star pattern on the pavement, and the elegant symmetry were revolutionary and symbolized a shift from medieval to Renaissance urban design.

Key Buildings Around the Square
1.	Palazzo Senatorio ‚Äì The central building at the rear, which still serves as the seat of Rome's city government.
2.	Palazzo dei Conservatori ‚Äì To the right; houses part of the Capitoline Museums (sculpture and artifacts).
3.	Palazzo Nuovo ‚Äì To the left; also part of the Capitoline Museums (Roman busts and statuary).

The Statue in the Center
‚Ä¢	A bronze equestrian statue of Emperor Marcus Aurelius, which symbolizes Rome's imperial glory.
‚Ä¢	The current statue is a replica; the original is preserved inside the Capitoline Museums to protect it from the elements.

places.address: 00186 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Villa Borghese is a sprawling urban park in Rome, featuring meticulously landscaped gardens, an artificial lake with a temple, and several villas that now house important museums. The park also includes an aviary, an orangery, and various other charming buildings and follies. It was designed in the English style by Scottish artist Jacob More for the Borghese family in the 1770s.

sources.snippet: Located near the city center, Villa Borghese is a park of extraordinary beauty that is well worth a visit. Walking through the greenery of Villa Borghese, you will feel like you have entered another world: the lawns and well-kept flowerbeds of the park, together with the winding paths and calm lakes, create a serene atmosphere, perfect for a pleasant afternoon walk or a romantic picnic. If you love nature, Villa Borghese also offers a number of outdoor activities and attractions.
sources.shortName: Romantic weekend in Rome: the most romantic places you cannot miss

sources.snippet: If you are wondering whether Rome has a ‚Äúcentral Park‚Äù to visit the answer is yes. Villa Borghese is a favourite for tourists and locals; dubbed as the central park, is situated in the heart of Rome and is a landscaped Garden containing Museums, buildings and attractions. Villa Borghese is the third largest park in Rome and its central location makes it the favourite green escape from the crowded tourist sights.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places In Rome During Autumn- Like A Local

sources.snippet: The park of Villa Borghese is one of the most famous in Rome, not only because it houses some of the most beautiful museums, but also because it is extremely central. Accessible from the beautiful panoramic terrace of the Pincio, you can walk the entire park and always discover new corners. Entering from Viale dell‚ÄôAranciera you arrive at the magical pond, super romantic that leaves everyone breathless.
sources.shortName: TOP 10 - Most Romantic Places in Rome

sources.snippet: A walk in the gardens of Villa Borghese ‚Äì what is more romantic than a walk in magical gardens, with fountains and musicians from all sides?. The gardens of Villa Borghese are large and beautiful gardens from the 17th century, designed in the English style. It is highly recommended to have a picnic there during the pleasant months of the year.
sources.shortName: Activities for couples in Rome

sources.snippet: Head over to the beautiful gardens of Villa Borghese for a romantic stroll or a quiet picnic in the lush greenery. Villa Borghese was built in the 17th century and now houses the largest private art collection in the world. The gardens themselves offer a small lake with rowing boats for hire and a small zoo; bike rental is also popular.
sources.shortName: Our Guide to the Most Romantic Places in Rome
Most Romantic Places In Rome

sources.snippet: The main park in the city is Villa Borghese and this spot is a favourite for both locals and tourists. It was built in the 17th century and used by the Borghese and Bonaparte families. Those wondering what to do in Rome can stroll arm in arm through the fragrant pathways.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things To Do in Rome | Sightseeing

sources.snippet: A true corner of paradise, with exotic plants, ducks and birds: the small lake of Villa Borghese is ideal for a romantic kiss on a colourful rowboat, under the impenetrable gaze of the muses, nymphs and divinities of the splendid Temple of Aesculapius.
sources.shortName: Sette cose romantiche da fare a Roma

sources.snippet: The Villa Borghese (no, not the film - the actual villa) was built by architect Flaminio Ponzio and commissioned Scipione Borghese who used it to throw parties and house his impressive art collection - now displayed at the Galleria Borghese museum.
sources.shortName: The 10 most romantic place in Rome, Italy

sources.snippet: This sprawling park is perfect for a peaceful picnic or a romantic rowboat ride on its serene lake. For an elevated experience, head to the Pincio Terrace within the gardens‚Äîit offers sweeping views of Rome, especially stunning at sunset.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Places to Propose in Rome, Italy

sources.snippet: With the bustle of Rome, getting away from the main hub of the city can be a nice escape for some romance. Villa Borghese is the third largest park in all of Rome and is ideal for both a stroll or good old-fashioned picnic.
sources.shortName: What Are The Most Romantic Things To Do In Rome?

sources.snippet: Another romantic place in Rome to visit during your stay, either on foot or by bike, is the Villa Borghese park.
sources.shortName: 10 Romantic places in Rome

places.name: Villa Borghese

reviews.text: I wish I had planned for more time here because wandering this park was a treat. There are nicely manicured paths to follow, many people biking and walking their animals. It was very peaceful and lovely.

Great park that felt safe. 5 euro pp to take a boat on the pond. Loved the plant life. Zoo at the edge of the park. Lots of fountains and statues. Much quieter than city streets. Not far from Spanish steps.

A nice place for a pleasant walk! Nothing terribly exciting but you can cycle, walk or take a buggy to explore the parks & gardens! A few cafes and eats around the place plus a nice little lake where you can row a boat if you choose!

places.address: 00197 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Basilica of Santa Maria in Trastevere is a grand Catholic church with a rich history dating back to the 3rd century. Located in the lively Trastevere district of Rome, it is celebrated for its 12th-century mosaics and lavish interior adorned with 22 Roman columns.

sources.snippet: Last but not least is the rather unlikely suggestion of a graveyard: the Non-Catholic Cemetery to be precise. With its otherworldly atmosphere and winding paths, this cemetery hosts the graves of many notable cultural figures, including the great Romantic Poets themselves: Keats and Shelley.
sources.shortName: Rome's most romantic places

places.name: Basilica of Santa Maria in Trastevere

reviews.text: Another important and beautiful basilica dedicated to Santa Maria. Do visit although this place can be slightly out of the city center and other attractions. There are much lesser people but still well visited by tourists and devotees. Spend a good 20 minutes here. Avoid talking loudly and be considerate. Purchase souvenirs and make a donation if you can!

Santa Maria in Trastevere is one of those churches that welcomes you with warmth and quiet beauty. The golden mosaics shimmer softly in the light giving the whole space a gentle glow that feels both sacred and human. It is not overwhelming but full of detail charm and peaceful energy. The atmosphere invites you to sit slow down and just take in the stillness. Surrounded by the lively streets of Trastevere the basilica feels like a calm retreat that holds centuries of quiet devotion. It is beautiful in a way that does not shout but stays with you long after you leave.

The Basilica of Santa Maria in Trastevere and its surrounding piazza are absolutely breathtaking at night, and I mean that in the most profound way.

The moment you step into the piazza, you're hit with this incredible glow. The basilica's facade, with its famous golden mosaics sparkling under the floodlights, feels almost supernatural, like a beacon in the vibrant chaos of Trastevere.

The entire scene feels magical and looks exactly like something you'd see on a postcard or in a movie.
The piazza itself is an event. It's buzzing with energy-a beautiful mix of locals out for an evening passeggiata, street artists performing, and travelers soaking in the atmosphere.

The fountains murmur, people chat and laugh on the steps, and the sound of music from nearby cafes fills the air. It's the kind of place that captures the very soul of a Roman evening.
However, amidst all that historical beauty and charm, we also saw a less-polished, grittier side of the city. As we were taking in the incredible sight of the basilica, we noticed some young spray painters at work nearby. It was a jarring and unusual contrast-this sacred, ancient space with its intricate art, set against the raw, modern graffiti being created right there in the piazza.

It pulls you out of the fairytale and reminds you that this place isn't just a preserved relic; it's a living, breathing, and sometimes messy part of the city.
Ultimately, that contrast is what made the experience so memorable.

The Basilica of Santa Maria in Trastevere at night is a powerful blend of ancient awe and contemporary life. It's beautiful, a little bit raw, and perfectly captures the spirit of this incredible neighborhood. It's a definite must-see.

places.address: Piazza di Santa Maria in Trastevere, 00153 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Gallerie Nazionali di Arte Antica - Palazzo Barberini is a Baroque palace located in the Trevi neighborhood of Rome. It houses the museum collection known as Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, which includes renowned artworks by Tintoretto, El Greco, Caravaggio, and more. The palace itself features impressive interiors, including the Pietro Cortona ceiling.

sources.shortName: Most Romantic Places In Rome

places.name: Gallerie Nazionali di Arte Antica - Palazzo Barberini

reviews.text:
Decided to hide here from the unexpected drizzle falling upon Rome, and couldn't be more pleasantly surprised. Took around two hours overall to see everything including a lovely garden a bit further into the gallery yard, and the rooms were almost empty during the last few working hours. Each time you enter a room with a gorgeous ceiling, your mouth falls open.
Caravaggio stuns as always, and you can wander around counting the number of Judith' and Holofernes' heads you can see portrayed by different artists. There's this one room that stands out-it feels malleable, grand, and intimate to a fault, despite other visitors craning their necks up near you. What a miracle, truly!

The Caravaggio exhibition at Gallerie Nazionali di Arte Antica has been a highlight of our visit to Rome.  It really is a once in a lifetime opportunity to see, up close and personal, so many stunning Caravaggio works of art at one exhibition. Tickets can be purchased online and the exhibition runs until July. Even though you can select a time which limits the numbers for each visit, we found that it was very busy and crowded. It is a small price to pay however to experience this wonderful exhibition. If you are in Rome and can get tickets, I highly recommend that you do.

Disappointing Experience at the Caravaggio Exhibition

As a huge admirer of Caravaggio, I traveled to Rome specifically to see the exhibition at Palazzo Barberini, along with a friend who is a professor of Fine Art. Sadly, the experience was deeply disappointing due to very poor organization.

Despite booking a specific time slot (8:20 PM) and paying ‚Ç¨18 per ticket, we were let in with large crowds of people, many of whom had later time slots. The staff didn't bother checking entry times, which led to extreme overcrowding inside. We had to wait up to 20 minutes just to see a single painting, and the air quality was terrible due to the number of people.

Even worse, audio guides were played aloud in various languages without headphones, turning what should have been a peaceful, respectful gallery visit into a chaotic, noisy experience. It felt more like a busy market than an art exhibition.

The exhibition catalogue was also disappointing-‚Ç¨40 for a generic book about Caravaggio that had little to do with the actual exhibition. I ended up buying a smaller one that was slightly more useful.

We weren't just random critics-we were excited, genuine visitors who expected a world-class experience and left feeling frustrated and let down. Palazzo Barberini seriously needs to reconsider how it handles high-profile exhibitions.

In the end, it felt more like a money-making machine than a well-organized, memorable cultural experience. A real shame, considering the incredible art on display.

places.address: Via delle Quattro Fontane, 13, 00184 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Teatro dell'Opera di Roma, originally known as Teatro Costanzi, is a historic 19th-century theater in Rome that offers visually dramatic and lavish opera productions. The venue hosts a variety of performances including classical symphonies, ballets, and world-renowned operas. During the summer, it sets up a magnificent stage in front of the ancient ruins of the Baths of Caracalla.

sources.snippet: The 1,600 seat Teatro dell‚ÄôOpera di Roma is one of the finest in the world. There‚Äôs a big programme of opera, ballet and dance during each season. Just imagine getting dressed up, enjoying dinner and then heading off to see some of the best performers in the world sing and dance from the heart, it doesn‚Äôt get more romantic than this.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things To Do in Rome | Sightseeing

sources.snippet: Head over to the famous opera house to witness a jaw-dropping opera or ballet. Built in the nineteenth century, this theatre is one of the best in Europe. A perfect evening or day activity, you and your partner will leave feeling refreshed and inspired.
sources.shortName: Our Guide to the Most Romantic Places in Rome

places.name: Teatro dell'Opera di Roma

reviews.text:
My wife and I recently attended the Rosso e il Nero ballet at the Teatro dell'Opera di Roma, and it was a truly unforgettable evening. From the moment we stepped inside, we were struck by the theater's blend of historic elegance and artistic grandeur.

The theater itself has a fascinating history, originally inaugurated in 1880 under the name Teatro Costanzi. Its neoclassical architecture, with lavish decorations and rich detailing, reflects the opulence of late 19th-century design. The theater has retained its majestic style while modernizing for today's performances. The beautiful crystal chandelier and red velvet seats add a sense of old-world charm, making the experience feel like stepping back in time.

The acoustics here are exceptional, and the ambiance only enhances the power of the performance. Watching Rosso e il Nero in such a setting was captivating. The orchestra was impeccable, bringing Tchaikovsky's music to life with depth and emotion, while the dancers moved with precision and passion that left us in awe.

If you're considering a visit, I recommend arriving early to take in the architecture and elegance of the space. The staff is attentive, and there's a small bar where you can enjoy a pre-show drink in the grand foyer. Whether you're a fan of ballet, opera, or just historical theaters, the Teatro dell'Opera di Roma is a must-visit experience that will leave you with beautiful memories of Rome's artistic heritage.

A perfect place for an extraordinary night out!

An unforgettable experience! Booking was seamless from start to finish. The show itself was absolutely breathtaking-pure magic on stage. We reserved balcony seating, which offered a perfect view and added to the charm. The decor and ambiance were stunning, steeped in elegance and history. The audience was unique, clearly made up of true music lovers. It's an ideal outing for couples, adding a romantic touch to the night. The staff and organizers were incredibly professional, stylish, and graceful. I truly loved every moment and can't wait to return.
Beautiful building, and very elite environment. The balcony seats are good only if you are sitting in the first line, otherwise too tight and can't see the scene properly.

places.address: Piazza Beniamino Gigli, 00184 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: The National Roman Museum - Palazzo Massimo is housed in a Neo-Renaissance palace and showcases a classical art collection featuring sculptures, mosaics, and gold jewelry. Residents of Rome and the Roman metropolitan area enjoy free access to this museum along with other publicly owned museums under the Musei in Comune system. The museum's traditional layout contains an extensive array of classical art, including marble and bronze sculptures, frescoes, mosaics, and jewels.

sources.shortName: Most Romantic Places In Rome

places.name: Museo Nazionale Romano, Palazzo Massimo alle Terme

reviews.text:
The National Roman Museum is one of my favorite places in Rome, and I always love coming back. This museum has a unique atmosphere and offers a fascinating glimpse into the history of ancient Rome.

Every visit is an unforgettable experience for me ‚Äì from the beautifully preserved mosaics and frescoes to the majestic statues that seem to tell stories from centuries past. I am especially captivated by the collection of classical sculptures, particularly the iconic statue of Emperor Augustus and the incredibly detailed bronze busts.

The museum is spread across multiple buildings, so there's always something new to discover. Palazzo Massimo is my personal favorite ‚Äì its frescoes and mosaics transport me to the lavish villas of ancient Romans. Plus, it's never too crowded, allowing me to fully appreciate the exhibits in peace.

If you love history and art, I highly recommend visiting. For me, it's a place where I feel connected to the past and where I always find a moment to reflect and admire the beauty of Roman civilization.

This is an archeological museum with 4 floors of displays but one display floor was closed in the lower basement level. Regardless, the antiquities are a fine way to bring to life all the brown/gray ruins around Rome left partially intact or in a near rubble pile state. Apply the color of every day Roman living quarters to those sites you have seen and just imagine what they once actually looked like with frescoes on walls of dinning, living, and bedrooms rooms. The intricate mosaics decorating walls and floors with scenes of everything they cherished in their life time. The sculptures and busts of heroes and legends adorning their homes, gardens and bathhouses. Now one begins to learn of the Romans way of life. Allow 3 hours to casually explore this ancient world treasure.

Great museum with loads of interesting items. Plenty of room inside. I would've loved to see The Boxer but sadly he was on loan somewhere else üòïAlso on our visit the aircon was broken. The staff had placed portable ones in every room but it was still a tad uncomfortable but despite that we managed to see everything and we had a lovely coffee in the cafe there. My mums in a wheelchair but they have access round the side and lifts for every floor and she enjoyed it too.

places.address: Largo di Villa Peretti, 2, 00185 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Located in Rome, the Mouth of Truth is a famous attraction due to the myth surrounding it. Visitors can also explore other attractions in the Eternal City such as Palazzo Doria Pamphilj, Altar of the Fatherland, Capuchin Crypt, and lesser-explored neighborhoods like Testaccio.

sources.snippet: Two of Romantic Rome‚Äôs most famous fictional lovers ‚Äì Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck in Roman Holiday ‚Äì really showed how to have romantic fun in the city of Rome. After you‚Äôve explored Rome by Vespa (more tips and tricks for driving a Vespa in Rome here) you should really take your partner for some light-hearted fun at the Mouth of Truth. Gregory Peck mimed getting his hand bitten off here but I‚Äôm sure you can go one better ‚Äì why not bring up all those controversial arguments that have been festering all holiday in the name of honesty?
sources.shortName: Romantic Rome: 5 ridiculously romantic places to visit in Rome

sources.snippet: At the church of Santa Maria in Cosmedin, there‚Äôs always a long line of would-be Audrey Hepburns out front ready to try their luck with the famous Bocca della Verit√† (Mouth of Truth). An ancient Roman fountain-head made famous by the film Roman Holiday, it is supposed to chop off the hand of faithless lovers. Another, less well-known treasure lies inside; the cool, quiet interior is subtly decorated, with nothing to distract from the beautiful inlaid-marble floor that dominates the space.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Romantic overlooked things do in Rome

sources.snippet: Well known for the film Roman Holiday, the Mouth of Truth (Bocca della Verit√†) is nothing more than a manhole in the shape of a marble mask. Yet despite its humble beginnings, cinema has immortalized it as one of the most romantic places in Rome ever. However, legend has it that it bites the hand of anyone who does not tell the truth, slipping it inside.
sources.shortName: TOP 10 - Most Romantic Places in Rome

sources.snippet: The skull of the priest is bedecked with flowers inside Santa Maria in Cosmedin ‚Äì but bones are rarely romantic. What IS romantic is the sake St. Valentine gave his life for: love.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Rome

places.name: Mouth of Truth

reviews.text: Line goes quickly. Super cool piece of history to see. The views inside the church were stunning. Don't forget to go into the tomb, underground.

The mouth of the tomb is located in the portico of the Vadilica di Santa Maria in Cosmedin. There is always a queue moves quickly, so you don't wait too long. Is believed that the ancient marble Roman disk in the shape of a man's face is believed to be a cover for a well or a manhole, but the legend says that it you lie and you place your hand on its mouth it will bite it off

We recently visited the Mouth of Truth in Rome. Be prepared for a very long queue! We also found that its location is quite a distance from other major attractions.
If you're on a tight schedule or have limited time for sightseeing in Rome, you might consider skipping this one. While it's an iconic spot, the time spent queuing and traveling to and from it might not be worth it if your time is precious.

places.address: Piazza della Bocca della Verit√†, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Gardens of Vatican City are a historic urban oasis dating back to the 13th century, featuring stunning Renaissance and Baroque fountains and sculptures. Visitors can admire unparalleled frescoes in the Sistine Chapel, which also hosts the Conclave for electing the Supreme Pontiff. The chapel is adorned with works by renowned artists such as Michelangelo, Botticelli, and Perugino. In addition to famous attractions like the Vatican Museums and St.

sources.snippet: The Vatican Gardens are often overlooked by tourists but after dealing with the crowds inside the Basilica and Museums, this is a perfect and tranquil oasis, with a wide variety of plants and trees, as well as fountains and sculptures. The gardens are meticulously maintained: the lawns and plants are carefully manicured and perfectly pruned. The air is filled with the sweet scent of blooming flowers, and the gentle sound of fountains and water features creates a peaceful atmosphere to relax and find freshness on a stifling day.
sources.shortName: The Ultimate Guide to Exploring Vatican City: Tips and Highlights for Every Traveller

sources.snippet: Visitors can also take a stroll in the Vatican Gardens and enjoy the peaceful greenery. While it may not be a typical romantic destination, the Vatican can still be a meaningful and special place for couples to visit, especially for those with a shared interest in history, art, or religion. And with its stunning architecture, beautiful artwork, and peaceful atmosphere, it's not difficult to see why some couples might find the Vatican to be a romantic place to visit.
sources.shortName: A Sacred Romance at the Vatican

sources.snippet: The Gardens of Vatican City, more popularly known as the Vatican Gardens, are a series of gardens and parks which cover nearly half of the state. Spread over 23 hectares, the gardens feature medieval fortifications, and monuments and buildings from the 9th century to present day. You will get to see opulent fountains, incredible winding paths, vibrant colored flowers, and magnificent oaks.
sources.shortName: 7 Vatican City Attractions You Cannot Miss

sources.snippet: Be inspired by the Vatican Museums ‚Äì 1400 rooms containing art and artefacts from over 3,000 years of Roman history. Not to forget the Sistine Chapel, that attracts more than 5 million visitors a year (equal to the population of Norway). Advance booking and tickets with fast-track entry are advised, but it‚Äôs a real must-visit.
sources.shortName: The 20 Most Romantic Places in Rome

sources.snippet: The Vatican Gardens are an expansive area of the city-state that is generally closed to the public. They contain a variety of buildings, fountains, and sculptures, set among beautifully landscaped lawns and gardens. Access is possible through guided tours, which must be arranged in advance.
sources.shortName: Vatican City: the most secret places and what to visit first

sources.snippet: Here, you can find a medley of plants, each with its own religious symbolism. For instance, the olive trees represent peace, and the cypress trees symbolize eternal life. These Vatican Gardens also host a piece of the Berlin Wall, a nod to the Church‚Äôs enduring commitment to unity.
sources.shortName: Things to do & see in Vatican City, the country inside Rome

sources.snippet: The Vatican City is the smallest country in the world and a sovereign nation completely encircled by walls. Inside those walls are wonders beyond belief. The Vatican Museums, Sistine Chapel, St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica, and of course the Vatican Gardens.
sources.shortName: 10 Things to See Near the Vatican City

sources.snippet: The Vatican Gardens offer the epitome of a private, romantic tour. This retreat from the bustle of Vatican City is a spot that many tourists miss.
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Rome for Couples
Where to Propose in Vatican City: 9 Best Places & Itinerary
A Guide to the Perfect Trip

places.name: Gardens of Vatican City

reviews.text: Spectacular experience if you have the opportunity. Get tickets in advance for a tour through the Vatican Museums. We went first thing in the morning on a summer morning and it was fantastic. The walking tour was about 1.75 miles, with two breaks to refill water bottles and one for the bathroom. Slightly hilly and with stairs in ways that could be problematic for individuals with mobility limitations, but I think there may be a bus-based option as well. A tranquil start to your day before the frenzy of the museums.....

A peaceful and unforgettable part of our Jubilee pilgrimage
‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

We visited Rome for the Holy Year and chose June for its warm but bearable weather ‚Äì the perfect time to enjoy the Vatican Gardens. The open bus tour was a highlight of our trip: peaceful, enriching, and visually stunning. The lush greenery, fountains, and sacred architecture created a deeply moving atmosphere.

The audio guide provided insightful commentary without being overwhelming ‚Äì it truly enhanced the experience. We loved every moment.

After the gardens, we entered the Sistine Chapel directly, skipping the museum galleries as we had visited them before. The chapel was very crowded, but still worth it ‚Äì a sacred space that never loses its impact.

We booked the garden visit about 2‚Äì3 weeks in advance, and it included the museum ticket. Absolutely recommended ‚Äì especially during the Jubilee year.

What a real gem to experience. I booked a guided tour of the Sistine Chapel/Museums which first included access to these gardens. I would definitely recommend it because they only do a select few tours a day inside the gardens so it's a nice break from the crowds inside the Vatican Museums! Our guide spent nearly 1.5 hours walking us around - we thoroughly enjoyed it, plenty of places to fill up water bottles as well which is really needed on hot days!

places.address: Viale Vaticano, 00165 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Ponte Vittorio Emanuele II is a majestic triple-arched Roman bridge in Rome, named after Victor Emmanuel II. Designed by architect Ennio de Rossi in 1886, it wasn't inaugurated until 1911. Spanning the River Tiber and connecting Vatican City with Piazza Venezia and Capitoline Hill, the bridge features large winged sculptures of the Roman goddess Victoria.

sources.snippet: Another wonderful walk is from Lungotevere dei Vallati cross Ponte Garibaldi bridge with the fantastic view of the Tiberina island and get to Lungotevere Raffaello Sanzio. From here you can either keep walking along the river or continue your romantic date in the Rome Trastevere neighborhood.
sources.shortName: 15 Wonderful Romantic Things to Do in Rome (2024 Edition)

places.name: Ponte Vittorio Emanuele II

reviews.text:
Rome- The Eternal City üáÆüáπüáªüá¶

Ponte Vittorio Emanuelle Bridge one of the greatest landmark of Rome.

We visited this place on 22nd and 23rd July 2023.

If you are around Rome üáÆüáπ Italy, Vatican, don't miss this beautiful bridge above River Tiber ü´°ü´∂üèª

A place with lots of History ‚ù§Ô∏èü´°

Nice place to visit! Attention to those guys trying to catch your attention with bracelets or putting things on you.

They are quite persuasive and pushy. We almost had a situation but The police acted fast, they saw we had been trying to politely reject the guy and he was insisting and following us, asking for money.

Ponte Vittorio Emanuele II is the bridge that connects the historic center of Rome to the area around the Vatican. It was built in the late 1800s and named after Italy's first king.

The bridge is decorated with big stone statues of winged victories and allegorical figures. From here, you get some of the best views of the Tiber River, Castel Sant'Angelo, and the dome of St. Peter's Basilica.

It's a great spot to take photos, especially at sunset. If you're walking to or from the Vatican, this bridge is the most scenic route. Worth crossing just for the views alone.

places.address: Lungotevere dei Fiorentini, 00186 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Tempio di Esculapio is a picturesque Ionic style temple located in the heart of Rome's Villa Borghese park. Accessible by a wooden pier, this 1786 structure sits amid a scenic lake, offering visitors a serene and beautiful setting to explore. The park itself is peaceful and gorgeous, with attractions such as the Terrazza del Pincio and Fontana Rotonda along the way to the temple.

sources.snippet: I am forgetful of everything but seeing you again¬ª wrote John Keats, one of the greatest English poets, whose last home was in Rome, just to the right of the Spanish Steps. The house-museum is one of the most evocative places in the city: if you love poetry, you will feel emotionally moved thinking of the verses of the great English romantic writers.
sources.shortName: Sette cose romantiche da fare a Roma

places.name: Temple of Aesculapius

reviews.text: A really lovely place with a great atmosphere and stunning natural surroundings. I visited early in the morning, so the boat wasn't open yet, but the price seemed to be around ‚Ç¨5. Definitely worth a visit!

Fun, cheap experience. ‚Ç¨5 pp for 20 minutes. Free use of the parasols as well. Nice opportunity to take photos. We had fun spotting the turtles popping their heads out of the water too. The water is a bit dirty however, litter floating past for example. Would do it again though.

This was so beautiful. Has been a highlight on my trip so far. You can also go on your own paddle boat for 5 euros per person. We didn't, but the atmosphere was amazing. There was a woman playing the harp, fish and turtles swimming and stunning scenery.

places.address: Via Ulisse Aldrovandi, 6, 00197 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Villa Farnesina, a 16th-century marvel located in Trastevere, Rome, is a stunning example of Italian Renaissance architecture. Designed by Baldassare Peruzzi and adorned with frescoes by renowned artists like Raphael and Sebastiano del Piombo, the villa exudes opulence and grandeur.

sources.snippet: Nestled in an out-of-the-way corner of Trastevere, the elegant  Villa Farnesina is a gorgeous Renaissance pleasure-palace constructed in 1511 by a Sienese banker madly in love. Having already enjoyed the company of a high-end courtesan and having failed to woo the daughter of the Marquis of Mantua, the banker fell for a lowly shop-keeper‚Äôs daughter of great beauty. Although their relationship met with disapproval, he took her as his common-law wife and housed her in this villa.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Romantic overlooked things do in Rome
Most Romantic Places In Rome

sources.snippet: Oh, you didn‚Äôt think a visit to one of Rome‚Äôs top art sites could be romantic?. That‚Äôs just because you‚Äôve never visited the Villa Farnesina. This stunning 16th-century palazzo‚Äîone of Rome‚Äôs most beautiful examples of Renaissance architecture‚Äîwas the ‚Äúsexy spot‚Äù of the Renaissance.
sources.shortName: The Most Romantic Places in Rome
Rome's most romantic places

places.name: Villa Farnesina

reviews.text: A must visit in Rome! There were barely any people and closed around 2pm on a Friday but the art and the history of the villa was amazing. Only 7‚Ç¨ entry for a great experience and a place to hide away from the summer heat.

A hidden gem in Trastevere. The Raphael frescoes are amazing. I loved all the fruits. We visited in March and all the citrus trees in their beautiful garden were full of fruit, and parrots. The Villa is very near the Rome Botanical Garden and visiting the two makes for a lovely afternoon.

This hidden villa provides rooms filled with art dating back to the 13th century. The art is really diverse and interesting,  some are disturbing, others are of beautiful landscapes! Whilst the building is huge, the visit didn't take too long to walk through as It was only a portion of the building itself.

places.address: Via della Lungara, 230, 00165 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Domus Aurea, or "Golden House," stands as a testament to the opulence of Emperor Nero's reign in ancient Rome. Constructed after the devastating fire of AD 64, this grand villa complex was envisioned to be an extravagant palace that would dwarf even the Vatican City today. Although it was never fully completed and later dismantled after Nero's death to return land to the Roman populace, its remnants reveal a world of luxury adorned with vibrant frescoes and exquisite marble sculptures.

sources.shortName: The 5 most romantic spot in Rome

places.name: Domus Aurea

reviews.text: Everything was wonderful, an astonishing view certain to leave you without words. Must see when in Rome, I would 100% recommend to book the guide directly from the official website, as she is both extremely intelligent and cultured as well as charismatic and very well spoken. The interactive experience is breathtaking, I felt like I was time traveling to ancient times. If you're not familiar with the history, I recommend reading at least a little bit on the topic before visiting, but the guide will make sure that everyone understands throughout the whole experience. She is very passionate about the whole thing and spoke very good spanish. Lovely lady with a great sense of humor! I am still in awe at the beauty of it all while writing this review!

I guess the most interesting place to discover in Rome and still not so known, which is great!
It's hard to Imagine the whole palace which is under the ground now was once an impressive and one of the best in the world .

The minus: hard to find the place. And why the hell you guys sell tickets in another building located right next to it?üòÅ

The Domus Aurea is an incredible experience for anyone with a keen interest in Roman ruins and with a fascination for looking back at lives and works from 2000 years ago.

I took a guided tour in Spanish led by the wonderful Claudia who was very knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the information she was sharing. Just an excellent tour, a joy to take part.

The Domus is a massive, mostly buried structure that archaeologists are still excavating to uncover and protect its remains from under centuries of rubble. You can see original lavish decorations from Nero's time and the original layout of the building along with functional additions (plain brick walls) from Trajan. You can see the actual point where they just stopped work on this megalomaniac project because Nero died. You can see a piece of false ceiling there that is still hanging from the walls 2000 years later, with its original fresco on it. You can see the sources of inspiration for Raphael and many other Renaissance artists who may have visited this buried building firsthand. You see directly where Raphael got his inspiration for the decor you see in his rooms in the Vatican. I found all of this amazing and I'm very happy that I visited.

The tour includes a very well done virtual reality experience (with goggles) that immerses you in what the palace must've been like originally: full of light, colours, and beauty.

I would recommend it to anyone who is deeply interested in ancient Rome and archaeology. I would not recommend it to somebody who just wants a quick and easy tick box.

Heads up that the tour takes about two hours  and it's fully underground. It is cold even in summer, and dark and humid. So wear warm clothing. I would not recommend going in without guidance because the educational guided tours enrich the experience enormously. Again, this is an active archaeological site and will be for the many years to come.

places.address: Vle della Domus Aurea, 00184 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: This Non-Catholic Cemetery is a quiet and peaceful place, popular among romantics due to the beautiful flowers and sculptures planted among the graves. It is also the final resting place of some famous authors, including John Keats and Percy Bysshe Shelley, as well as Antonio Gramsci, the founder of Italy's Communist Party.

sources.snippet: Last but not least is the rather unlikely suggestion of a graveyard: the Non-Catholic Cemetery to be precise. With its otherworldly atmosphere and winding paths, this cemetery hosts the graves of many notable cultural figures, including the great Romantic Poets themselves: Keats and Shelley.
sources.shortName: Rome's most romantic places

places.name: Non-Catholic Cemetery

reviews.text: The Non-Catholic Cemetery in Rome is a hidden gem worth visiting. Nestled near the Pyramid of Cestius, it offers a peaceful and picturesque setting with lush greenery, artistic gravestones, and notable burials, including poets Keats and Shelley. Entry is free, but a ‚Ç¨5 donation is suggested to support its upkeep. The cemetery's tranquil atmosphere and historical significance make it a unique spot to explore Rome's cultural heritage off the beaten path. Whether you're drawn by its beauty or its history, it's a serene place to reflect and admire.

The grounds here were amazing to walk through and take in the vast amount of memorials, headstones and tombs. All they ask is for a 5 euro donation, which is more than fair. This is also the site of the pyramid of Caius Cestius, as well as a protected cat sanctuary. Definitely worth a visit, and not overcrowded like most areas of Rome. As an added bonus, they have a restroom as well!

A Peaceful Gem Tucked Beneath Rome's Layers of History

Tucked quietly beside the bustle of Roman life, the Non-Catholic Cemetery is far more than just a resting place-it's a hidden haven of calm, character, and cinematic views. From the moment you step through the gate, there's an unmistakable shift in pace. The world softens. Even the breeze seems to move slower here.

The layout is lush yet contemplative, scattered with benches nestled among the stone paths, each offering moments of quiet reflection or just a pause from your itinerary. One of the biggest surprises? The stunning view that opens up from within-framed perfectly between cypress trees and ivy-strewn walls is the Pyramid of Cestius, standing like a sentinel in the background. Nearby, Porta San Paolo and the adjacent castle-like structure lend an almost fairytale layer to the vista. It's surreal-like wandering through a scene designed for thoughtful exploration.

This place isn't just picturesque; it's steeped in story. Graves of artists, poets, and thinkers line the shaded trails, some with tributes so heartfelt they feel like whispers left behind. And yet, there's no heaviness here. It's gentle, peaceful-even uplifting.

Whether you're escaping the heat, dodging the crowds, or just craving a spot to breathe with beauty, the Non-Catholic Cemetery deserves your time. No ticket queues. No shouting tour guides. Just you, the timeless stones, and a view that quietly demands your attention.

places.address: Via Caio Cestio, 6, 00153 Roma RM, Italy

places.generalDescription: Exploring the Vatican Necropolis is like stepping into a hidden chapter of history beneath the grand Basilica of Saint Peter. Nestled 5 to 12 meters below Vatican City, this ancient burial site was unearthed during significant archaeological excavations from 1940 to 1949. The discovery revealed that this sacred ground is believed to be the final resting place of St. Peter himself, along with other popes and early Christians who faced persecution under Emperor Nero.

sources.snippet: Also known as the Vatican Scavi, the Vatican Necropolis lies beneath St. Peter's Basilica. The Necropolis, a Roman cemetery with elaborate tombs, was excavated between 1940-49 under the orders of Pope Pius XII, to find the burial site of St. Peter. The first centry necropolis has corridors where once the first Christians walked, and you can too.
sources.shortName: 7 Vatican City Attractions You Cannot Miss

sources.snippet: Beneath St. Peter's Basilica lies the Vatican Necropolis, a small city of the dead that includes mausoleums, monuments, and tombs dating back to the Imperial era. It is here that the Tomb of St. Peter is believed to be located. Access to the Necropolis is highly restricted, with visits allowed only by special permission.
sources.shortName: Vatican City: the most secret places and what to visit first

places.name: Vatican Necropolis

reviews.text:
Visiting the necropolis beneath St. Peter's Basilica was an unforgettable experience. Unlike most attractions in Rome, you can't just turn up-you need to book in advance. Book your unique experience at Saint Peter's Necropolis by choosing your preferred date and time, and the Excavations Office will confirm your visit based on availability. You can make your request at the official booking site.

The tour begins with a descent down narrow steps, leading you deep beneath the basilica. As you pass through glass doors, you enter a hidden world-an ancient Roman necropolis with well-preserved mausoleums, frescoes, and inscriptions left by early Christians. The atmosphere is eerie yet mesmerizing, a quiet, sacred space untouched by time.

The highlight is reaching the area believed to hold the tomb of St. Peter himself. Standing there, seeing the relics of one of Christianity's most important figures, is a humbling experience, whether you're religious or simply a lover of history.

The groups are small, and the guides are incredibly knowledgeable, making this one of the most exclusive and insightful experiences in Rome. If you're looking for something truly special beyond the usual Vatican visit, this is absolutely worth doing!

It was an interesting place. I saw Pope John Paul II's tomb, he was alive during my time. To be able to see the tombs of past Popes, each one with different personalities to match how they lived their lives was‚Ä¶ just different.

Sadly, instead of feeling peace and spirituality in the Vatican, my boyfriend and I experienced aggression and humiliation - right at the entrance. We came from a nearby side to avoid walking around a metal barrier - not jumping it, not breaking any real rules. But the guard who saw us reacted in a way that did not reflect the values of a holy place. His anger, shouting, and hostility felt more like something representing darkness than anything sacred.

It felt as though this man served not the religion of love and forgiveness, but something quite the opposite - something harsh, cold, and far from the light. It was deeply disappointing to face such a spirit in the very heart of the Catholic Church.

places.address: Piazza San Pietro, 00120 Citt√† del Vaticano, Vatican City

places.generalDescription: Parco Regionale dell'Appia Antica is a historic park that stretches along 16 km of the ancient Roman road. It offers a glimpse into the past with well-preserved tombs and villas. This pathway, once crucial to Rome's military and economic activities, provides an opportunity to immerse in the city's history while surrounded by picturesque natural landscapes. Visitors can explore catacombs, ancient villas, and various historical sites along this iconic route.

sources.snippet: Rome is a city to stroll through hand in hand - try to find a view from one of the many hills, a square or a bridge particularly at sunset. However, if your idea of romance calls for something less chaotic than the city centre, escape to the peace and tranquillity of Rome‚Äôs most ancient highway and walk back through the ages along the original Roman road, the Appia Antica...
sources.shortName: Romantic Things to Do in Rome

places.name: Parco Regionale dell'Appia Antica

reviews.text: Great for a break from the city bustle. It's quaint, it's almost rural, and definitely has the "antique" vibe. If one has time and resources, there are some museum&sights that can be visited along the Parc, but even without visits to those, the road itself is a beautiful place.

It's in the city but you don't see, hear or feel the city. Its wild, pure nature surrounding you is absolutely incredible. In summer months be prepared to take extra water as it might be a bit hot and for sure you would not want to miss all the views and the hike here.

P.S. - you can find a trail here that leads you to pipes residence Castel Gandolfo it's only 18km from that park.

The bike ride took me all day as I wanted to stop off at every site along the map and see everything. So if your like me, plan for an entire day, bring lots of drinks and snacks. It's definitely worth the trip, so much to see and do along the way. And if you make it to then end they give you a pin. It's a long bike ride and it's a little bumpy but lots of fun, I've done with people and solo. I would highly recommend taking a nice bike ride along the way. Or walk if you like but you won't see nearly as much.

places.address: Via Appia Antica, 42, 00178 Roma RM, Italy
